content.description: The 2nd from the left, of the routes on the crag. Nice route! Sustained. As noted below searching for a hold toward the anchors is helpful when getting to the top and clipping the anchors.
content.protection: 4 bolts to anchors. As of April 2020, the chains have hardware store snaplinks on them and should be replaced if anyone is so inclined.Â

content.description: The right-most route of the now four routes on the Ed Woody wall. Start near (on) the trail at the edge of the wall and clip two bolts to a big ledge. Ever steepening moves above lead past a big, semi-loose horizontal crack to green lichen-covered rock for a few more moves to the chains.
content.protection: Seven bolts to chain anchors.  This is a newer route and some loose stuff still exists in spots so test those holds!
content.location: This is the right-most route on the Ed Woody wall. Two other starts exist in addition to the one list above. One can start at the new platform area in the hill side and go directly to the second bolt. Or, one can do and unprotected scramble up the sloping ledge to clip the third bolt as the first one.

content.description: High first bolt and some tricky moves to a good rest.  Step around arete after the last bolt to keep the route at easy 5.10.  Better finishes are to finish straight to the anchors 5.11, or the best finish 2-3 stars is to finish on Redline the next route to the right.
content.location: On Far left side of Ed-Woody Wall

content.description: The 2nd route from the right on the crag. Start just above a ledge, the first bolt is high. Continue up, most of the holds go right of the smoothish face.
content.protection: 6 bolts to anchors. Anchors are a bit funky.

content.description: West-facing crag with 4 routes. Stays in shade into the early afternoon in the summertime (longer than the majority of the south facing crags).
